results.headline: Crankier Than Thou, but Open to New Love
results.summary_short: Matthew Broderick adopts just the right attitude for his role in “Wonderful World.”

results.headline: Apocalyptic Beliefs of American Evangelicals
results.summary_short: “Waiting for Armageddon” is a spine-tingling reminder that some prophecies are self-fulfilling.

results.headline: Ireland in February, With Romance in the Air, Manure on the Ground
results.summary_short: “Leap Year” is so witless, charmless and unimaginative that it can be described as a movie only in a strictly technical sense.

results.headline: Total Recall: A Journey From Vienna to Brooklyn and the Center of the Brain
results.summary_short: “In Search of Memory: The Neuroscientist Eric Kandel” invites you to spend an hour or two in the presence of a Nobel Prize winner.

results.headline: Montana Cowboys Lead, Coax and Cajole Their Charges Amid a Chorus of Bleats
results.summary_short: The wonderful documentary “Sweetgrass” is the first essential movie of this young year.

results.headline: Death of a Golden Boy Ripples Through a Family
results.summary_short: “A Year Ago in Winter” doesn’t succumb to the usual weepie-of-the-week clichés.

results.headline: The Struggles of Cairo’s ‘Garbage People,’ but No Whining
results.summary_short: “Garbage Dreams” digs deep into the politics of a life that few would choose but many depend on.

results.headline: Struggling Actor Tweaks Script, Buddy and Bodies
results.summary_short: “A Film With Me in It” is a slender, supple comedy graced with appealing performers and laced with agreeable poison.

results.headline: Wholesome Hamlet’s Horror Sends a Jolt to the System
results.summary_short: “The White Ribbon,” by Michael Haneke, is an unnerving but unsatisfying chronicle of a German village filled with hidden cruelty, set on the eve of World War I.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The White Ribbon

results.headline: Ox Is Part of the Family, and Then Some
results.summary_short: The inscrutable dignity of animals may seem strange when encountered in a documentary like “Old Partner.”

results.headline: Gasping for Breath in a Prison of Gentility
results.summary_short: “The Loss of a Teardrop Diamond,” starring Bryce Dallas Howard as an emotionally unstable heiress in 1920s Memphis, exhumes an obscure Tennessee Williams screenplay.

results.headline: Down Those Mean Streets of Seoul, on the Double
results.summary_short: The South Korean thriller “The Chaser” evokes both film noir and the television police procedural in its straightforward storytelling.

results.headline: Legendary Breakups: Good (Animated) Women Done Wrong in India
results.summary_short: “Sita Sings the Blues,” Nina Paley’s new animated film, is ambitious and visually loaded.

results.headline: The Brawling Supersleuth of 221B Baker Street Socks It to ’Em
results.summary_short: There are worse things than loutish, laddish cool, and as a series of poses and stunts, “Sherlock Holmes” is intermittently diverting.

results.headline: A Traveling Show Comes to Town, but Its Guests Are the Ones on a Journey
results.summary_short: Terry Gilliam’s latest is a full three-ring affair, complete with puffs of smoke, glitter and grunge, some hocus-pocus, mumbo jumbo and even a dwarf.

results.headline: A September-September Romance
results.summary_short: In the pleasurable, daffy if at times daft “It’s Complicated,” Meryl Streep takes a character and makes you love her.

results.headline: Jiggers: Here Comes the Dictionary!
results.summary_short: True to its title, the new Romanian film “Police, Adjective” is a story of law enforcement with a special interest in grammar.

results.headline: A New Eden, Both Cosmic and Cinematic
